ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: What it means to actually translate a text
Basic translation theory, important examples of translation and how to analyze them, how to work on your own translation

I learned about the historical and current practices of translation, how to read more critically, and how to approach texts as a translator would (compared to how a reader would). I also learned how to more effectively provide feedback for the translations of others.
I learned a great deal about different modes, theories, and styles of translation, and became more familiar with some of the most widely read pieces of world literature.
This course taught me how to approach literary translation and how to create translations that capture the spirit of a work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - Workshop format, diversity of texts was very helpful for learning about different modes of translation.
Weaknesses - Workshops might've been a little too free and left up to students' discretion. Maybe some guidelines as to what kind of feedback would be helpful/looked for (for instance, more overarching translation practices as opposed to simple grammar/wording choices) would have been good.

This was a fantastic course. It does a really good job trying to combine both a literature seminar-style syllabus and a creative writing sort of final project. One of the biggest strengths of the course is Professor Creswell and Maru, who are so helpful, very rigorous in their comments, and super available to meet with students. I learned so much just from office hours for this class. The only suggestion I would have would be to add more short translation assignments from the target language before you start working on your final translation. I like to get a chance to "practice" a little bit more.

I think that this course was incredibly engaging, and I appreciated the balance that was struck between seminar discussions and workshops. The readings (at times a little heavy) would be very interesting to the point where we would rarely be able to go through all of them in the course of one class period. There would never be an instance where the discussion would stagnate.

I would always receive very detailed, helpful feedback on nearly all of my assignments. In fact, I would have appreciated if some of the later assignments had gotten similar levels of feedback (although I understand that this is difficult when the assignments are to be posted on a class-wide discussion forum).

This was a great course! I really enjoyed the readings and the structure of the class time. I think one thing that could improve the experience of the workshops would be a time cap on individual comments-- sometimes those would take almost the entire class and there wasn't much time for broader discussion. I also think it would be interesting (if it were possible) to pair people up who are working from the same language and maybe have those people give more in-depth feedback to each other during the workshops? Just an idea. Overall, though, I really enjoyed this course.
The strength of this course is that you read a wide variety of texts from differents languages and cultures on translation that enrich your understanding of the tradition.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to any student who has an interest in translation of any kind. More voices from people outside of the comp. lit department would be great!

Yes. It's not a low time commitment, and you should be prepared to work on a decent-length translation. However, I got so much out of this class and I would recommend that anyone who speaks another language (and has any interest in literature and storytelling) should take this class.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I think that it is a class that even non-Humanities students would enjoy and would be able to get a lot out of. Although there is the caveat of being fluent in at least one language other than English, I think that the experience of taking this class is very rewarding, and it is very exciting to see ones translations of a text develop, as well as those of ones peers in the class.
Yes, absolutely! I think the topics covered are applicable to a wide variety of interests and fields of study.
Yes, I recommend this course to anyone who is a writer and lover of languages.
I couldn't recommend this course more. It's very well-organized, the readings are incredible, and the feedback on your work you receive from your peers and professors is extremely helpful.
